001// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
002// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
003// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.
004
005package edu.wpi.first.wpilibj;
006
007import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Seconds;
008
009import edu.wpi.first.hal.DriverStationJNI;
010import edu.wpi.first.hal.FRCNetComm.tInstances;
011import edu.wpi.first.hal.FRCNetComm.tResourceType;
012import edu.wpi.first.hal.HAL;
013import edu.wpi.first.hal.NotifierJNI;
014import edu.wpi.first.units.Measure;
015import edu.wpi.first.units.Time;
016import java.util.PriorityQueue;
017
018/**
019 * TimedRobot implements the IterativeRobotBase robot program framework.
020 *
021 * <p>The TimedRobot class is intended to be subclassed by a user creating a robot program.
022 *
023 * <p>periodic() functions from the base class are called on an interval by a Notifier instance.
024 */
025public class TimedRobot extends IterativeRobotBase {
026  @SuppressWarnings("MemberName")
027  static class Callback implements Comparable<Callback> {
028    public Runnable func;
029    public double period;
030    public double expirationTime;
031
032    /**
033     * Construct a callback container.
034     *
035     * @param func The callback to run.
036     * @param startTimeSeconds The common starting point for all callback scheduling in seconds.
037     * @param periodSeconds The period at which to run the callback in seconds.
038     * @param offsetSeconds The offset from the common starting time in seconds.
039     */
040    Callback(Runnable func, double startTimeSeconds, double periodSeconds, double offsetSeconds) {
041      this.func = func;
042      this.period = periodSeconds;
043      this.expirationTime =
044          startTimeSeconds
045              + offsetSeconds
046              + Math.floor((Timer.getFPGATimestamp() - startTimeSeconds) / this.period)
047                  * this.period
048              + this.period;
049    }
050
051    @Override
052    public boolean equals(Object rhs) {
053      return rhs instanceof Callback callback && expirationTime == callback.expirationTime;
054    }
055
056    @Override
057    public int hashCode() {
058      return Double.hashCode(expirationTime);
059    }
060
061    @Override
062    public int compareTo(Callback rhs) {
063      // Elements with sooner expiration times are sorted as lesser. The head of
064      // Java's PriorityQueue is the least element.
065      return Double.compare(expirationTime, rhs.expirationTime);
066    }
067  }
068
069  /** Default loop period. */
070  public static final double kDefaultPeriod = 0.02;
071
072  // The C pointer to the notifier object. We don't use it directly, it is
073  // just passed to the JNI bindings.
074  private final int m_notifier = NotifierJNI.initializeNotifier();
075
076  private double m_startTime;
077
078  private final PriorityQueue<Callback> m_callbacks = new PriorityQueue<>();
079
080  /** Constructor for TimedRobot. */
081  protected TimedRobot() {
082    this(kDefaultPeriod);
083  }
084
085  /**
086   * Constructor for TimedRobot.
087   *
088   * @param period Period in seconds.
089   */
090  protected TimedRobot(double period) {
091    super(period);
092    m_startTime = Timer.getFPGATimestamp();
093    addPeriodic(this::loopFunc, period);
094    NotifierJNI.setNotifierName(m_notifier, "TimedRobot");
095
096    HAL.report(tResourceType.kResourceType_Framework, tInstances.kFramework_Timed);
097  }
098
099  @Override
100  public void close() {
101    NotifierJNI.stopNotifier(m_notifier);
102    NotifierJNI.cleanNotifier(m_notifier);
103  }
104
105  /** Provide an alternate "main loop" via startCompetition(). */
106  @Override
107  public void startCompetition() {
108    robotInit();
109
110    if (isSimulation()) {
111      simulationInit();
112    }
113
114    // Tell the DS that the robot is ready to be enabled
115    System.out.println("********** Robot program startup complete **********");
116    DriverStationJNI.observeUserProgramStarting();
117
118    // Loop forever, calling the appropriate mode-dependent function
119    while (true) {
120      // We don't have to check there's an element in the queue first because
121      // there's always at least one (the constructor adds one). It's reenqueued
122      // at the end of the loop.
123      var callback = m_callbacks.poll();
124
125      NotifierJNI.updateNotifierAlarm(m_notifier, (long) (callback.expirationTime * 1e6));
126
127      long curTime = NotifierJNI.waitForNotifierAlarm(m_notifier);
128      if (curTime == 0) {
129        break;
130      }
131
132      callback.func.run();
133
134      callback.expirationTime += callback.period;
135      m_callbacks.add(callback);
136
137      // Process all other callbacks that are ready to run
138      while ((long) (m_callbacks.peek().expirationTime * 1e6) <= curTime) {
139        callback = m_callbacks.poll();
140
141        callback.func.run();
142
143        callback.expirationTime += callback.period;
144        m_callbacks.add(callback);
145      }
146    }
147  }
148
149  /** Ends the main loop in startCompetition(). */
150  @Override
151  public void endCompetition() {
152    NotifierJNI.stopNotifier(m_notifier);
153  }
154
155  /**
156   * Add a callback to run at a specific period.
157   *
158   * <p>This is scheduled on TimedRobot's Notifier, so TimedRobot and the callback run
159   * synchronously. Interactions between them are thread-safe.
160   *
161   * @param callback The callback to run.
162   * @param periodSeconds The period at which to run the callback in seconds.
163   */
164  public final void addPeriodic(Runnable callback, double periodSeconds) {
165    m_callbacks.add(new Callback(callback, m_startTime, periodSeconds, 0.0));
166  }
167
168  /**
169   * Add a callback to run at a specific period with a starting time offset.
170   *
171   * <p>This is scheduled on TimedRobot's Notifier, so TimedRobot and the callback run
172   * synchronously. Interactions between them are thread-safe.
173   *
174   * @param callback The callback to run.
175   * @param periodSeconds The period at which to run the callback in seconds.
176   * @param offsetSeconds The offset from the common starting time in seconds. This is useful for
177   *     scheduling a callback in a different timeslot relative to TimedRobot.
178   */
179  public final void addPeriodic(Runnable callback, double periodSeconds, double offsetSeconds) {
180    m_callbacks.add(new Callback(callback, m_startTime, periodSeconds, offsetSeconds));
181  }
182
183  /**
184   * Add a callback to run at a specific period.
185   *
186   * <p>This is scheduled on TimedRobot's Notifier, so TimedRobot and the callback run
187   * synchronously. Interactions between them are thread-safe.
188   *
189   * @param callback The callback to run.
190   * @param period The period at which to run the callback.
191   */
192  public final void addPeriodic(Runnable callback, Measure<Time> period) {
193    addPeriodic(callback, period.in(Seconds));
194  }
195
196  /**
197   * Add a callback to run at a specific period with a starting time offset.
198   *
199   * <p>This is scheduled on TimedRobot's Notifier, so TimedRobot and the callback run
200   * synchronously. Interactions between them are thread-safe.
201   *
202   * @param callback The callback to run.
203   * @param period The period at which to run the callback.
204   * @param offset The offset from the common starting time. This is useful for scheduling a
205   *     callback in a different timeslot relative to TimedRobot.
206   */
207  public final void addPeriodic(Runnable callback, Measure<Time> period, Measure<Time> offset) {
208    addPeriodic(callback, period.in(Seconds), offset.in(Seconds));
209  }
210}
